1432803335040536587.text: I also expect the Biden Administration will remain vigilant against threats to our security and will continue using all available diplomatic avenues to secure the rights and safety of those who remain in Afghanistan.

1432803333820006413.text: Additionally, I am committed to providing refugees with the support they need to rebuild their lives.

1432803332368781317.text: I have been working tirelessly with Oregonians to help their family members flee Afghanistan, and I will persist in doing all I can to make sure our Afghan allies and those most at risk under Taliban rule are able to leave the country safely.

1432803330401710083.text: I am grateful for the servicemembers who have dedicated themselves to protecting our nation and working to improve the lives of Afghans, particularly their heroic effort in recent days to assist more than 120,000 people in escaping the country.

1432803329059471368.text: The U.S. must do everything possible to avoid again becoming involved in a long, protracted war.

1432803327692189696.text: After 20 years, the U.S. has withdrawn its troops from Afghanistan. The withdrawal comes after decades of lives tragically lost, including the deaths of 13 servicemembers in the final days. We will always remember and honor their ultimate sacrifice.

1432777384961482758.text: I condemn the violence we have seen in Portland and across the country. Today I joined @SenJeffMerkley, @RonWyden, & @repblumenauer in calling on the @TheJusticeDept to investigate the interstate actions of domestic extremists, including the Proud Boys. https://t.co/dQMpKaBjvN

1431377367138803724.text: And for those who remain in Afghanistan, we must continue advocating for the protection of human rights and ability to live a life without fear of violence.

1431377366161444864.text: I’m also committed to increasing resources to support resettlement, both in the US and abroad, to help these families secure a brighter and more secure future.

1431377365012303882.text: Withdrawing from Afghanistan is necessary, and doing so after 20 years was always going to be difficult. I have many questions about the process, but right now our focus needs to be the evacuation of US citizens, our Afghan allies, women who are at risk, and others.

1431377363762352132.text: Their stories are heartbreaking, and I am continuing to do all I can to advocate for their safe and expeditious evacuation.

1431377362629824513.text: We’ve been working to help people in extremely dangerous situations, including a child waiting to be reunited with their family in NW Oregon, a man in the final stages of the SIV application process, and a single parent with young children whose family is being threatened.

1431377361480601725.text: Over the past weeks, my office and I have been in constant contact with families and friends of dozens of loved ones who are trying to escape Afghanistan.

1341208594113568769.text: It is reprehensible that for months Senate Republicans fought our efforts to get this urgent relief to our communities and the people who need it. I will continue fighting for more aid to help our families, workers, and businesses stay safe, recover, and rebuild.

1341208487888564224.text: This relief package will make a meaningful difference to our communities, but it is not nearly enough to fully account for the damage from the COVID-19 pandemic.

1341208314483535873.text: The bill will also help keep families in their homes by extending the moratorium on evictions and providing rental assistance.

1341208284011835392.text: Food insecurity has been increasing across Oregon and the country, and this bill increases SNAP benefits and provides funding for child nutrition programs to help make sure families and children do not go hungry.

1341208189086412806.text: We also know that our economy will not recover until parents, and particularly mothers, can access affordable child care. I am glad that this legislation includes $10 billion in child care assistance, but without more we will not see an economic recovery.

1341208090318925824.text: Importantly, this bill includes relief funding for schools and institutions of higher education that will help them better meet the needs of their students during the pandemic, including funding that can help schools prepare to reopen to students.

1341207994634280965.text: Unfortunately, many small, independent restaurants are closing daily. This bill takes some steps to help them, but not enough, and I won’t let up in my fight to secure the additional aid they need.

1341207913025695745.text: This new relief package also expands support for small businesses, which are the lifeblood of our communities and our economy. There are provisions to help independent venues, the arts, nonprofit organizations, and more.

1341207832646070272.text: This is much less than the ongoing, direct cash assistance to Oregon families I’ve been advocating for throughout the pandemic, and it is infuriating that we could not convince Senate Republicans to provide more direct relief to people in such dire need.

1341207719135612928.text: Additionally, the bill provides a new round of $600 direct payments for individuals and families, including many families who were previously denied assistance because of the immigration status of a household member.

1341207633215320064.text: The bill passed today also includes a critical extension of unemployment insurance for nearly 72,000 Oregonians, and a $300 per week enhancement of the benefits, which will help provide a lifeline to so many people who are out of work.

1341207539908800512.text: This relief package will accelerate the distribution of vaccines, improve testing, and help overcome the barriers faced by communities of color. https://t.co/m2O5oTC2wO

1341207412037042176.text: Fortunately many frontline health care workers in Oregon and across the country have already received vaccinations, but we know it’s going to take a massive effort to make vaccines available to all.

1323991228988510210.text: This decision is reprehensible, and demonstrates a gross failure of leadership that will continue to harm our country and the planet.

1282797402261528577.text: I will continue to fight for critical funding, for reopening decisions that are based on science, and for all students to receive the quality public education they deserve.

1282797330777935873.text: This Administration’s rhetoric is dangerous but not surprising. It is indicative of a pattern that consistently ignores the significant needs of public school students, especially students of color and low-income students.

1282797072803037185.text: The House passed the Heroes Act to provide $915 billion for state and local governments, and importantly, make a $58 billion investment in K-12 schools. The Senate must immediately pass this legislation to invest in our students and our future.

1282796944176422912.text: The $13 billion for K-12 schools in the CARES Act was a start, but this is far from the investment that’s needed.

1282796799737159688.text: The federal government must fulfill its role of advancing equity in education by providing our public schools and districts with substantial, additional funding to make sure they can equitably serve students and keep everyone in the school building safe.

1282796755092897792.text: We all want our schools to safely reopen, but they will need our help.

1282796497793425409.text: The vast majority of funding for public education comes from state and local governments, not the federal government. Unfortunately, because of the pandemic, state and local governments are facing a $615 billion revenue shortfall.

1282796259791835146.text: Reopening schools is incredibly important to address these challenges and make sure all children receive a quality education, but the decision to reopen must be based on science and must make the health and safety of students, teachers, staff, and families the top priority.

1282796164677545991.text: School districts are buying and distributing technology for remote learning, educators are working to contact and inspire students, and counselors are trying to address social-emotional needs virtually.

1282796047409061888.text: Over the past few months, teachers, parents, students, and school counselors and psychologists have told me about their struggles. Parents strive to keep students on task while balancing work responsibilities, but it’s stressful and extremely challenging.

1282795859437133829.text: In addition, only 6 out of 10 low-income students have been participating regularly in remote instruction, compared with 9 out of 10 of their higher-income peers.

1282795792273747970.text: Research indicates that learning loss will be worse for Black and Latinx students (10 months and 9 months, respectively) compared with the expected 6 months of learning loss for white students.

1282795680654856192.text: Our public education system faced serious challenges in Oregon and across the country before COVID-19, and the pandemic has exacerbated inequities and widened the achievement gap.

1282795616901443591.text: No school should be threatened into reopening before it is safe to do so, and the Secretary’s threat to withhold federal funding is an empty one because she has no legal right to do so.

1282795484134940673.text:
Make no mistake – Secretary DeVos’ plan to force schools to reopen is dangerous to students, educators, and school staff. 

https://t.co/fDjCwnfqe4

1272657969352753152.text: When George passed, a vivid rainbow appeared in the sky over Portland. The Supreme Court ruling on equal rights this morning was Mom’s rainbow. Rest in the peace you marched for, Mom. I miss you already.

1272657888612319232.text: On June 14, she passed peacefully in her sleep. I have so much gratitude for all of her caregivers, especially Kris and then Magda, Odette, and Aura, who showed her love, respect, and compassion over the last 10 months.

1272657799584124930.text: A two-time cancer survivor, Mom was tough and strong. But when she developed Alzheimer’s, and when she lost George to cancer in 2016, she began to decline.

1272657718495543296.text: Mom & Dad grew apart and split up, then George, always a romantic, found her again. They married in 1979. Over the past several decades, Mom and George owned G/M Galleries in Massachusetts, then in Portland’s Multnomah Village. They closed the gallery when they reached their 80s.

1272657596588097540.text: Then in the 1960’s, she left her position as church organist because the church wouldn’t take a stand on civil rights. In Northville, Michigan, she owned the Sunflower Shop, which sold arts & crafts, beads, natural supplements, organic vegetables, sunflower seeds, and more.

1272657502413471745.text: When my mom was in high school, she dated two men – my dad Roland Bonamici and George Woodcock. She married my dad, they had three kids (I’m sandwiched between my brothers), and we settled into suburban life.

1272657398059196420.text: Now I truly respect that she was ahead of her time; open-minded, curious, creative, and comfortable with who she was.

1272657336872599553.text: She grew organic vegetables, marched for civil rights, gave piano lessons in our living room, painted bright hard-edge paintings late into the night, told stories about the Detroit Folklore Society, & would take my brothers & me to @DIADetroit and camping for long periods of time

1272657073873059845.text: When I was young, I wanted my mom to be like the other moms. But she wasn’t. https://t.co/4bfzWBJH7Y

1272575545096708097.text: Discrimination is wrong, and no one should have to fear for their job because of who they are. Today the Supreme Court affirmed that LGBTQ individuals are protected from discrimination on the job, and cannot be fired for being gay or transgender.

1261753181513678850.text: Throughout the years, our friendship continued. My heart goes out to his family, especially to his dear wife Harriet, who was always by his side with a smile. Rest in peace, Mitch. Oregon will not be the same without you.

1261753088660123655.text: Mitch would always speak his mind; something I respected and saw in full display when we did town hall meetings together.

1261752991687860224.text: Soon after, I became the volunteer coordinator for his 2000 campaign. In 2007 I served with him on the House Health Care Committee, and I will always remember the thought-provoking, philosophical discussions we had on the topic of why health care is a human right.

1261752891481772034.text: The first time I met Mitch, he impressed me so much that I came home with his trademark campaign bookmark and announced to my family that I wanted to help him get elected.

1261752839979913216.text: Mitch Greenlick was a kind and brilliant man with integrity and passion for serving the public. He was a mentor and a friend, and I will miss him greatly.
